Learning Ruby Notes

  1. Introduction

    • Why do we need to learn this?
      • Learn how to simply manipulate computers
      • Simple but foundational language
      • Familiarizes with directory and file manipulation
    • Lots of memorization
      • Notecards are suggested

  2. Exercise 1: The Setup

    • Linux/OSX Commands
      • pwd ~ print working directory
      • hostname ~ my computer's network name
      • mkdir ~ make directory
      • cd ~ change directory
      • ls ~ list directory
      • rmdir ~ remove directory
      • pushd ~ push directory
      • popd ~ pop directory
      • cp ~ copy a file or directory
      • mv ~ move a file or directory
      • less ~ page through a file
      • cat ~ print the whole file
      • xargs ~ execute arguments
      • find ~ find files
      • grep ~ find things inside files
      • man ~ read a manual page
      • apropos ~ find what man page is appropriate
      • env ~ look at your environment
      • echo ~ print some arguments
      • export ~ export/set a new environment variable
      • exit ~ exit the shell
      • sudo ~ DANGER! become super user root DANGER!

  3. Exercise 2: Paths, Folders, Directories (pwd)

    • The ">" symbol is used to prompt the user ($ for Unix)
    • pwd stands for "print working directory"

  4. Exercise 3: If You Get Lost

    • To go to default path, type 'cd ~'
    • Print pwd and then cd ~

  5. Exercise 4: Make A Directory

    • Make new Directory by using 'mkdir' and 'mkdir -p' for bigger directories for Linux/OSX
    • Directories are the same as folders
    • / can be used, but \ is the usual one to use

  6. Exercise 5: Change Directory (cd)

    • Use '..' to navigate up the tree/path

  7. Exercise 6: List Directory (ls)

    • dir -r and ls -lr print absolutely everytning

  8. Exercise 7: Remove directory (rmdir)

    • rmdir (dir) to remove

  9. Exercise 8: Moving Around (pushd, popd)

    • 'pushd' takes current directory and pushes into a list for later, changes it to another directory
      • 'save where I am, then go here'
    • 'popd' takes last directory you pushed and 'pops' it off, taking you back there
    • Doesn't work in powershell

  10. Exercise 9: Making Empty Files (Touch, New-Item (windows))

    • Example on Windows
      • New-Item example.txt -type file

  11. Exercise 10: Copy a File (cp)

    • cp (doc to copy) (name of copy)

  12. Exercise 11: Moving a File (mv)

    • Moving (renaming files)

  13. Exercise 12: View a File (less, MORE)

    • less for linux and more for windows

  14. Exercise 13: Stream a File (cat)

    • Cat displays all of a file

  15. Exercise 14: Removing a File (rm)

    • Have to delete all files within a directory to remove it

  16. Exercise 15: Exiting Your Terminal (exit)

    • Exit is your friend

General Notes

* -r recurssively edits directories, manipulating all internal files within

About Me

Howdy! I'm Tristan. I'm a computer science: information systems major and a new media minor at UNC Asheville. This is where I post all of the coding notes and blurbs I write for my internship at Herrmann International. Take a look around!
